messages: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:58): "Woohoo, I'm gonna be famous!" - who's going to break the news to them that that typo was already reported on Bugzilla? :-)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:59): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, where is that quote from?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:00): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I think you are focusing on the wrong misapprehension
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (16:04): wonders how many of those typos could be fixed with a spell checker
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:09): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/single-page/,spell
590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10 (16:11): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: That would have been me. Bah, knew that had to be too easy. :)
590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10 (16:11): Guess I'll just have to work harder for immortality.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:12): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: or, alternatively M-x flyspell-mode
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:13): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Inline spellchecking in Emacs. It seems more useful as a solution since it allows the errors to be corrected
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:14): there's something weird about that W3C spell checker, since it's freezing Minefield
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:19): 590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10: You could also hope that Hixie gets confused by timezones and thinks your email was sent before the Bugzilla bug was filed
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:21): that spell checker should ignore <code>
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:22): That wouldn't help with typos in code comments
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:22): I wrote getElementsByClassName
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:22): hopefully people can read over that
590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10 (16:23): Actually I have some other errors up my sleeve.
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:28): 590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10, you'll now be known as the guy that tried to get his name in HTML5 by reporting a spelling error... and failed! :D
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (16:29): That's probably better fame-wise than being one among hundreds of acks in the spec
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:30): 590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10, I can see how this might not be funny to you. Fortunately you were planning on doing more review :)
590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10 (16:32): It is funny, I just like making sad faces.
590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10 (16:33): Besides, I'm sure the XHTML2 group would be more than happy to receive my spellcheck powers! Ha!
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:35): But they won't make you famous unless you join their WG
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:36): You can get famous in the XHTML2 WG? I thought you languished in academic obscurity
590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10 (16:36): Ah well. Never mind then.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:36): HTML5 is happy to give equal fame to cats as to browser developers
590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10 (16:36): Maybe I should have my cats report typos then.
590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10 (16:37): My time-travelling cats, that is.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:37): Yeah it true that the acknowledgements list is too long. Maybe I should train some cats to kill the other people on it
590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10 (16:37): Anyway, back to work now. I guess I'll report future stuff in Bugzilla.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:39): I don't think there's much value in using Bugzilla rather than the list

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:40): I suppose there might be a bit of value in checking both Bugzilla and the list for duplicates before posting, but that's not too important since we'll let Hixie deal with it :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:40): so it's probably best to just do whatever's easier
590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10 (16:40): Well, at least I can try to be less redundant by seeing what's already been reported there.
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:43): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, where you put the dual tokens leaks in one way or another
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:43): using bugzilla for reporting spec bugs is useful because it keeps the volume of traffic on the mailing list lower
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:44): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, so the spec will have to dicate something
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:44): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Why is lowering volume on the mailing list a goal?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:45): For typos it generates the same amount of mail
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:45): because it means discussions like that on bug 6684 don't generate too much noise
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:45): 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db: It doesn't leak if you make createElementNS lowercase and throw upon importing non-lowercase node from an XML doc
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:46): 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db: but I'm not convinced that plugging the leak is worthwhile
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:46): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, that's because bugzilla has been misconfigured to send new bugs to public-html instead of just public-html-bugzilla
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:47): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Almost the entire purpose of the mailing list is to have discussions, so it seems discussions should go there
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:47): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, what exactly is your strategy?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:47): 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db: do you mean implementation strategy?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:47): (Bugzilla might be more useful for things there's no point in anyone except the editor reading and no need for discussion, like typos)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:48): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, in principle, yet. But experience with public-html suggests that it's useful to try and keep as much unproductive discussion off the list as possible, so that the little bit of productive discussion that goes on there doesn't get drowned out in the noise
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:49): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, what is the alternative to what I posted for getElementsByTagName?

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:51): 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db: the alternative is that each element node has a pointer to an interned compound name struct (aka. node info in Gecko and qualified name in WebKit) and this struct has pointers to four interned items:
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:51): namespace, local name, prefix and ASCII-lowercased local name
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:52): then in XML, selectors preserve case and match against local name
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:52): and in HTML selectors are lower-case and match against ASCII-lowercased local name
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:53): making SVG-in-text/html nodes give the appearance of case-insensitive selector matching
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:54): that's not just a different strategy, that gives different results
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:54): and the third alternative is using a single local name atoms on both sides and magic fixup lists that can't support textArea
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:54): 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db: different results
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:55): i think what bz said makes the most sense
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:55): that's also what i said on IRC yesterday... :)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:55): so, yeah I guess there's no way around the spec forcing which side you put the dual atoms on
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:56): 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db: yesterday I didn't know that bz would be OK with HTMLness compare plus pointer compare instead of just pointer compare :-)
590325cab98d895113e22a5a703a0f10 (16:56): Hey, shouldn't this page: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/ include the newly separated specs? Or are they listed somewhere else?
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:57): they moved to the W3C
